bill_title: Requesting the United States Forest Service to quickly address the poor health of the Black Hills National Forest.

bill_versions.bill_text: A CONCURRENT RESOLUTION, Requesting the United States Forest Service to quickly address the poor health of the Black Hills National Forest. WHEREAS, the people of South Dakota depend upon a healthy forest in the Black Hills to provide clean air, clean water, diverse wildlife, recreation, forage, and wood products; and WHEREAS, the United States Forest Service estimates that 450,000 acres of the Black Hills National Forest is at moderate or high risk for serious insect infestation or is rated as a high fire hazard, and that this acreage will increase to 585,000 acres over the next decade as forests grow; and WHEREAS, the State of South Dakota has filed a lawsuit against the United States Forest Service claiming that the United States Forest Service has unreasonably delayed its mandatory, statutory duty "to make provisions for the protection against the destruction by fire and depredations upon the public forests and national forests"; and WHEREAS, current growth on the Black Hills National Forest is estimated at 189 million board feet per year; and WHEREAS, the allowable sales quantity for the Black Hills National Forest is 83.8 million board feet per year, yet officials of the Black Hills National Forest have arbitrarily limited the timber sales program to 70 million board feet per year; and WHEREAS, the harvest limit prevents forest managers from attaining healthy stocking levels in an economical manner; and WHEREAS, a new allowable sales quantity will be established as part of the Phase II Amendment to the Black Hills National Forest Revised Plan: NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED, by the House of Representatives of the Seventy- ninth Legislature of the State of South Dakota, the Senate concurring therein, that the United States Forest Service be requested to include within the Phase II Amendment to the Black Hills National Forest Revised Plan an allowable sales quantity adequate to significantly reduce the acreage of the Black Hills National Forest currently at risk of insect infestation and fire and adequate to ensure healthy forest conditions in the Black Hills National Forest for future generations; and BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the United States Forest Service be requested to enact the Phase II Amendment no later than November 1, 2004; and BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that the United States Forest Service be requested to aggressively implement management programs outlined in the Phase II Amendment beginning in 2005.
